> > Выглядит как-то совсем непонятно. Хотя и оригинал немного странный.
> 
> Единственное замечание — не хватает запятой перед «чем». Добавлю её. Смысл ясен: одним из отличий git от централизованных СУВ является высокое быстродействие, но следует помнить, что локальный репозиторий будет работать быстро только при быстром файловом доступе к содержимому папки «.git»; если файлы физически расположены на удалённом сервере, то «локальные» операции на самом деле потребуют сетевого взаимодействия, что может поставить крест на скорости.

А мне смысл не ясен. По ходу изложения материала о локальном протоколе подразумевалось, что на NFS лежит только главная копия репозитория, а каждый разработчик всё равно делает себе локальную копию и работает именно с ней. Поэтом я не особо понимаю к чему тут этот абзац. А если имеется в виду, что все разработчики работают с одной и той же копией, то это вообще бред, ибо такого не может быть -- при одновременной работе постоянно будут конфликты.

Не надо сильно разбивать коммит на части, достаточно разбить на 4 коммита -- по одному для каждой главы. Тем более тут это сделать совсем несложно:
$ git stash
$ git reset orgin/master
$ git add ru/01-*
$ git commit -m '[ru] chapter 1: fix some mistypes'
$ git add ru/02-*
$ git commit -m '[ru] chapter 2: fix some mistypes'
...
$ git stash pop
$ git push --force

. > This is an invalid url which git will reject:
> `ssh://user@server:project.git`

This notation works for me with Git-1.7.9. Besides, everywhere in the book the first notation is used for ssh urls, so it's probably better to drop 'ssh://' part instead of changing ':' to '/'.
. Not specifying protocol explicitly could mean either `git://` if you write `user@server/project.git` or `ssh://` if you use scp-like notation. So i suggest following fix:

```
To clone a Git repository over SSH, you can specify ssh:// URL like this:

    $ git clone ssh://user@server/project.git

Or you can use shorter scp-like syntax for SSH protocol:

    $ git clone user@server:project.git

You can also not specify a user, and Git assumes the user you’re currently logged in as.
```

Смысл ясен: одним из отличий git от централизованных СУВ является высокое быстродействие, но следует помнить, что локальный репозиторий будет работать быстро только при быстром файловом доступе к содержимому папки «.git»; если файлы физически расположены на удалённом сервере, то «локальные» операции на самом деле потребуют сетевого взаимодействия, что может поставить крест на скорости.

. Not specifying protocol explicitly could mean either `git://` if you write `user@server/project.git` or `ssh://` if you use scp-like notation. So i suggest following fix:

```
To clone a Git repository over SSH, you can specify ssh:// URL like this:

    $ git clone ssh://user@server/project.git

Or you can use shorter scp-like syntax for SSH protocol:

    $ git clone user@server:project.git

You can also not specify a user, and Git assumes the user you’re currently logged in as.
```

. I have not pushed this pull request. 

If I understand it correctly, you had problems with a file initially coded with CR-only line endings. This file would not be correctly processed in your application.

To me, a decent text editor should be able to read any text file, whatever the line ending type. In fact, it should even be able to let you create a file with the line-ending of your choice. Basically, the only thing to focus on for this section of the book is the _default_ line-ending type that the OS environment is meant to process.

Sure, a bash script can be written with CR+LF line-ending, but the default for bash is LF. All the files originating from MacOSX that I have seen until now are unix type. As said, CR only is some kind of legacy mode.

Now, on to the gitattribute not working. If you try to feed a CR-only file while using gitattribute for LF, it seems normal to me that git will not change anything: with this configuration, git expects the file to have LF as line-endings.  In fact, git does not process CR as end of lines at all.
. > Anyway, it turns out git on MAC doesn't normalize text files which have CR-only line endings, even when you force normalization via gitattributes.

It seems that this needs a bug report with a testcase to the git project.

> And 'default' on MAC is LF for some (tools coming from the UNIX realm) and CR for others, 

Would you dare proposing a sentence to add to the book, based on your experience?

. It is true that this kind of workflow is not described in the book, and even discouraged. It is generally a bad idea to force-push a branch.

That's one of the shortcomings of git on the semantic level. Most of the time, when someone wants to send changesets to a project via a branch and there is need for a fixup these changesets (that might be needed after peer review), the branch needs to be forcefully pushed. It is just that this branch should not be considered a "real branch" but a mere pile of patches. Git has no way to tag these kinds of branch and easily allow force-push.

I think it should be described in advanced topics. It is quite common. @schacon What do you think?
. Github does not sync anything between forks of a project by itself. It is up to you to update your local repo from the upstream repo and push these updates to you Github fork.

When your branch is already based on the tip of the upstream repo and your changes are merged in the upstream  repo, the upstream repo reaches the same state as you had in your local repo. So, in this case, the upstream repo is actually sync'ing with you. That's usually why git tells you that you are already up to date when you fetch after.

. I just had a look at the source file for the management of dates in git project (namely `date.c`) and this is both surprising and interesting. This file deals with dates on its own and does not resort to using advanced system primitives.

Doing so, a lot of inaccuracies are introduced. For instance, the summer time shifts are not taken into account, with the following comment:

```
/*                                                                                                                                                                      
 * Check these. And note how it doesn't do the summer-time conversion.                                                                                                  
 *                                                                                                                                                                      
 * In my world, it's always summer, and things are probably a bit off                                                                                                   
 * in other ways too.
*/
```

 Even better, date in the format dd.mm.yyyy might be tried as mm.dd.yyyy if for some reason, the first format can not lead to a plausible date (real date in the past). A lot of fun. And you can even specify `--since=tea`...

There's enough to fill a full chapter.
. I think the issue with time zone applies mostly with "approxidate". If you run `git log --since="5 months ago"` in june, the shift will not be taken into account. That's incorrect, but does missing an hour really matter when you are crawling 5 months backward?

If I understand it correctly, you had problems with a file initially coded with CR-only line endings. This file would not be correctly processed in your application.

To me, a decent text editor should be able to read any text file, whatever the line ending type. In fact, it should even be able to let you create a file with the line-ending of your choice. Basically, the only thing to focus on for this section of the book is the _default_ line-ending type that the OS environment is meant to process.

Sure, a bash script can be written with CR+LF line-ending, but the default for bash is LF. All the files originating from MacOSX that I have seen until now are unix type. As said, CR only is some kind of legacy mode.

Now, on to the gitattribute not working. If you try to feed a CR-only file while using gitattribute for LF, it seems normal to me that git will not change anything: with this configuration, git expects the file to have LF as line-endings.  In fact, git does not process CR as end of lines at all.
. > Anyway, it turns out git on MAC doesn't normalize text files which have CR-only line endings, even when you force normalization via gitattributes.

It seems that this needs a bug report with a testcase to the git project.

> And 'default' on MAC is LF for some (tools coming from the UNIX realm) and CR for others, 

Would you dare proposing a sentence to add to the book, based on your experience?

When you create the commit by running `git commit`, Git checksums each subdirectory **list** (in this case, just the root project directory) and stores those **as** tree objects in the Git repository. Git then creates a commit object that has the metadata and a pointer to the root project tree so it can re-create that snapshot when needed.

. It is true that this kind of workflow is not described in the book, and even discouraged. It is generally a bad idea to force-push a branch.

That's one of the shortcomings of git on the semantic level. Most of the time, when someone wants to send changesets to a project via a branch and there is need for a fixup these changesets (that might be needed after peer review), the branch needs to be forcefully pushed. It is just that this branch should not be considered a "real branch" but a mere pile of patches. Git has no way to tag these kinds of branch and easily allow force-push.

I think it should be described in advanced topics. It is quite common. @schacon What do you think?
. Github does not sync anything between forks of a project by itself. It is up to you to update your local repo from the upstream repo and push these updates to you Github fork.

When your branch is already based on the tip of the upstream repo and your changes are merged in the upstream  repo, the upstream repo reaches the same state as you had in your local repo. So, in this case, the upstream repo is actually sync'ing with you. That's usually why git tells you that you are already up to date when you fetch after.
. Well, it is not rebased. But It can be merged.

. I just had a look at the source file for the management of dates in git project (namely `date.c`) and this is both surprising and interesting. This file deals with dates on its own and does not resort to using advanced system primitives.

Doing so, a lot of inaccuracies are introduced. For instance, the summer time shifts are not taken into account, with the following comment:

```
/*                                                                                                                                                                      
 * Check these. And note how it doesn't do the summer-time conversion.                                                                                                  
 *                                                                                                                                                                      
 * In my world, it's always summer, and things are probably a bit off                                                                                                   
 * in other ways too.
*/
```

 Even better, date in the format dd.mm.yyyy might be tried as mm.dd.yyyy if for some reason, the first format can not lead to a plausible date (real date in the past). A lot of fun. And you can even specify `--since=tea`...

There's enough to fill a full chapter.

GerHobbelt:
Sorry to barge in following up on seeing this in the email track, but yesterday I suffered from the MAC ~ CR issue badly: I got into trouble because a HTML file had been created and used - without trouble - on a MAC. IIRC it was created using jEdit but it may have been another editor.
Anyway, the platform is a modern MacBook Air, browser id says it's Intel OSX 10.7, and
  od -a <file>
showed that the file was CR-only line endings.

I only got into trouble because the file was renamed to PHP and MAC MAMP (Apache+PHP) barfed a hairball in the PHP interpreter because that was the first time on that MAC that CR was _not_ accepted.

The point is that MACs still create CR-only text files -- I assume this depends on which tools you use to create the text files -- and CR-only is definitely a MAC problem that shouldn't 'disappear from sight' like this:
.gitattributes: *.php text eol=lf
didn't 'fix' the problem for some odd reason (git 1.17.2), which still has got me spooked. The problem only went away after using that gitattributes _and_ forcibly converting the entire file to LF only with an editor on my own Windows box, then commit once again. (Offering a LF-only index file to git on MAC didn't make those CR's go away, hence the second attempt via my own dev machine.)

The old text is indeed 'wrong' (MAC does both CR and LF these days), but the new text you are using now is very much 'wronger'.
I hope that bit of text in the book will at least help others 'recall' there's this bloody MAC issue that can hit you at the worst of times.
. Well, the 'default' on MAC doesn't seem to be LF for everybody, it isn't about what you might/can do, it's what you get off a vanilla system; the files with those CR line endings were created by someone who had not tweaked/altered default settings in any way, used a very recent version of an editor for the MAC and got, without his knowledge, files with CR line endings. Which did fine. Until they didn't.
When you get that sort of stuff together with git, then, yes, you're bound for trouble some day, as was I.

The mentioned gitattributes line works for Windows+UNIX at least, as it is meant to store and output such files as LF-only, no matter what your line endings are when committing. ( as per http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/gitattributes.html ) I've been using it for a long time like that, but never got to work on a MAC until now.

Anyway, it turns out git on MAC doesn't normalize text files which have CR-only line endings, even when you force normalization via gitattributes. And 'default' on MAC is LF for some (tools coming from the UNIX realm) and CR for others, ergo on modern OSX: YMMV. 

And that's what should be taken home from all this: Today's MAC still has got stuff on board which does 'legacy' CR-only by default without telling you so. Cave canem.

When you get that sort of stuff together with git, then, yes, you're bound for trouble some day, as was I.

The mentioned gitattributes line works for Windows+UNIX at least, as it is meant to store and output such files as LF-only, no matter what your line endings are when committing. ( as per http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/gitattributes.html ) I've been using it for a long time like that, but never got to work on a MAC until now.

Anyway, it turns out git on MAC doesn't normalize text files which have CR-only line endings, even when you force normalization via gitattributes. And 'default' on MAC is LF for some (tools coming from the UNIX realm) and CR for others, ergo on modern OSX: YMMV. 

And that's what should be taken home from all this: Today's MAC still has got stuff on board which does 'legacy' CR-only by default without telling you so. Cave canem.
.

В действительности нет ничего страшного в том, чтобы повторно и параллельно использовать одни и те же объекты, если они неизменяемые. Всё, что меняется (голова, индекс, ветки и теги, конфиг и т.п.), разумеется, по-настоящему локальное. Я, пожалуй, соглашусь, что это может оказаться неочевидно для неподготовленного читателя, не знакомого с идеей скрипта git-new-workdir. Более того, от использования ссылок при клонировании по локальному протоколу можно отказаться в пользу «честного» копирования, и тогда доступ к данным будет таким же быстрым, как при других способах клонирования. Возможность использования жёстких ссылок сама по себе не является ни преимуществом, ни недостатком — это компромисс между плюсами и минусами: (+) экономия дискового пространства; (+) быстрое клонирование практически за константное время (для упакованной базы) независимо от размера репозитория; (–) задержки при обращении к файлам через ссылки; (–) невозможность работать удалённо при отсутствии связи (об этом вскользь сказано, что из дома нужно монтировать сетевой диск). . . I beg to differ.  If there's one thing I have learned in the past 3 years
of managing this project it is that people won't read warnings and
caveats.  I have had people ignore the word "FATAL" in an error message and
continue on, I have had people miss boldface text and blunder on.

However, I guess I can add basic install and setup instructions, a few rule
set examples, and leave the rest as pointers.  This is because I am kinda
hoping gitolite won't have any more changes, at least in those basic topics.

I'll make another PR this weekend.  Thanks for your thoughts on this.

sitaram

dsbonev:
How about this way:

By running `git commit` Git checksums each directory and each file and stores those as `tree` and `blob` object types respectively in the Git repository. Git then creates a `commit` object type that has the metadata and a pointer to the root project tree object so it can re-create that snapshot when needed.
. How about this way:

. Thanks Jean-Noël,

I would like to ask you, whether there are any tools (that possibly also you use) for easier synchronization of the translation with changes in the original. I am using some scripts for checking. It is based on keeping as exact structure of the translated sources as possible. Some elements (like code samples) are checked to be exactly same, for other elements only the types are checked (i.e. title of some level, para, list item, etc.). Then it checks for keeping the inline markup (typically the bacticked text), and some typo conventions (like using the localized double quotes where the double quotes are part of the displayed text).

However, I do not check whether some wording was changed inside a paragraph. I know that I could look for changes in the English original via Git... But this is the job for eyes, and fixing the translation based only on that is error prone.

Do you use any special tools for that task? Do you know whether other translators (people) around the Pro Git use any special tools?

Thanks,
    Petr

P.S. I am thinking about using OmegaT, but I have no working knowledge. But I was earlier impressed by MemoQ (commercial tool for the same purpose that uses the same basic principles).
. > I am curious to see the script that you set up.

You can get them from https://github.com/pepr/progitCZ. They are in the `util` subdirectory. But they are written in Python, and the comments are mostly in Czech. But they are written so that they could be adopted to another language.

The gen.py implements iteration through the lines of the full document (source files concatenated).

The docelement.py module defines the Element class that represents a parsed element of the document.

The pass1.py is the first pass parser (Czech comments), and the pass2.py is the second pass parser that uses the results of the first pass. (There actually were more parsers when I was converting the Czech PDF to the .markdown sources.)

The main script is csSync.py. The other scripts are modules used from the one. The main script assumes that the progit and progitCZ subdirectories are cloned to the same directory. The progitCZ/util uses relative paths to get the progit/en and progit/cs sources.

The script displays on console something like that:

```
e:\Literatura\Git\ScottChacon_ProGit\progitCZ\util>py csSync.py

. Thanks Jean-Noël,

I would like to ask you, whether there are any tools (that possibly also you use) for easier synchronization of the translation with changes in the original. I am using some scripts for checking. It is based on keeping as exact structure of the translated sources as possible. Some elements (like code samples) are checked to be exactly same, for other elements only the types are checked (i.e. title of some level, para, list item, etc.). Then it checks for keeping the inline markup (typically the bacticked text), and some typo conventions (like using the localized double quotes where the double quotes are part of the displayed text).

However, I do not check whether some wording was changed inside a paragraph. I know that I could look for changes in the English original via Git... But this is the job for eyes, and fixing the translation based only on that is error prone.

Do you use any special tools for that task? Do you know whether other translators (people) around the Pro Git use any special tools?

Thanks,
    Petr

P.S. I am thinking about using OmegaT, but I have no working knowledge. But I was earlier impressed by MemoQ (commercial tool for the same purpose that uses the same basic principles).
. > I am curious to see the script that you set up.

You can get them from https://github.com/pepr/progitCZ. They are in the `util` subdirectory. But they are written in Python, and the comments are mostly in Czech. But they are written so that they could be adopted to another language.

The gen.py implements iteration through the lines of the full document (source files concatenated).

The docelement.py module defines the Element class that represents a parsed element of the document.

The pass1.py is the first pass parser (Czech comments), and the pass2.py is the second pass parser that uses the results of the first pass. (There actually were more parsers when I was converting the Czech PDF to the .markdown sources.)

The main script is csSync.py. The other scripts are modules used from the one. The main script assumes that the progit and progitCZ subdirectories are cloned to the same directory. The progitCZ/util uses relative paths to get the progit/en and progit/cs sources.

PhiLhoSoft:
> What is the reason for using custom converter? Are you sure that graffle can't export diagrams in the svg format?

OmniGraffle is a commercial program, for Mac only. So I cannot use it, and perhaps jnavila cannot either.

> I think it does, but it will require some manual work :) And using some specialized editor like Dia or Graffle is a truly better way to edit diagrams :)

I am not opposed to use SVG, as it is a more universal format.
Dia is OK, as it is free (and open source, and portable), I installed it to be able to edit the .dia files. Although it is awful to edit text (no way to select a whole text at once to replace it!).
The problem with Inkscape is that it will tend to add its own private markup, unless saving as "clean" SVG.
Moreover, GUI editors often make awful history tracks as they might reorder the generated XML file...
But manual editing of SVG files (eg. in a text editor) isn't a real solution as we often need to adjust the text positions (to keep alignment).
. OK for the quotes, the commit can be skipped (I hope I haven't put anything else in it).
I carefully made the changes only where there will not be any ambiguity (no gobbling in them) but I understand the objection.
Alternatively, perhaps we can put a warning at the start of the book?
The msysGit installer gives the choice between shells, and I chose the system one out of habit. I know I have to use double quotes in this case, but newbies can be confused. There is also an issue with ^ finishing a command, BTW.
. - entête : l'orthographe recommandée est en-tête, même s'il est vrai que l'alternative est acceptée.
- clef vs. clé : la motivation principale est effectivement la cohérence. J'ai choisi l'orthographe recommandée dans le fichier glossaire-git.adoc...
. The English commit about quotes can be dropped safely: the only additional changes was about consistency of single quotes style in English sentences.
The French one must be reverted manually, as there are other significant changes (my bad).
. Merci. Effectivement, pas de problème si tu fais ces corrections toi-même,  ce sera plus simple... :-)
Merci pour ta relecture et tes remarques pertinentes.
. Pour info, j'ai quand même fait un dernier commit sur cette branche, tenant en compte tes remarques. À toi de voir si cela peut t'être utile.

testforpyide:
我拷贝的en中最新的部分翻译的，和之前的内容有些不一样。
. 这个diff文件已经不能正确的显示我翻译的内容，因为我翻译的英文内容不是diff中显示的内容。zh目录中第4章的原文件是比较旧的，最新的en文件的第四章已经改动了很多了。我2周前从en目录的第四章中拷贝了gitolite部分把原文件的英文部分给覆盖了。你可以看最新的en目录下的第四章的gitolite部分，那才是我翻译的源内容。具体的修改过程你也可以查看我fork的master分支。第一个修改把英文源替换了的。
. 第一个地方可以修改如下：
假定你拥有的是一个git、perl、以及openssh兼容的ssh服务器端都安装成功的服务器，你都不需要root权限来安装Gitolite。

第二个地方是我的习惯。相比一些固定的概念，我更喜欢用口语化的表达。我比较反感很多人在交谈过程中到处拿概念去套。多一些变化，也许能助于读的人理解知识本来的意思。当然，纯粹是我的习惯。
. 什么是自定义安装呢？

我的理解，就是一些调整而已。原文也是这样的，some changes。
. 自定义安装和调整就是一件事情嘛。你读一下原文。原文就是这样一会儿说customize install，一会说some changes。为什么转成中文，你就要帮别人进化一步呢？英文说some changes就等效于自定义安装，中文说一些调整他就不等效于自定义安装了？
. 我觉得也可以改成“(对安装)的一些调整”，这样表达也许更完整一些。
. 忠于原文的话，我觉得还是直译“some changes”，“有一些调整”。我反复读了译文，是没有问题的。只是需要读者对linux下程序的配置安装有基本的经验。原文那样写，也对读者有这个要求的。
. 完整就是安个自己都不懂的概念？
. 概念就是自己定义的一个名词。比如“自定义安装”，“多级授权”之类的。
. 我觉得读原文能读明白是因为英语总是习惯往中文转译，对不清楚的地方会多想一点。所以这种问题自己处理了。
读中文总希望能把脑子里面处理过的结果拿出来，觉得这样更符合中文的语言习惯。
但是，我在处理这些过程的时候会非常谨慎。比如你提的问题1就是英文习惯中的省略，而中文没有这样的习惯省略，属于翻译要调整的部分。但是第二个问题，属于用不同的描述表达同一个语义。原文如此，中文也应该如此，这样不仅可以保留原文的味道，也保留了原文对读者的要求。我总是力求保留原文的味道，虽然不可能百分百做到。
. 味道就是味道。你说一个美女有味道是因为她的鼻子还是嘴巴呢？哈哈
. @jnavila, @lbfalcons gave two comments about my translation. I accept one, but reject the other one. We can't make an agreement about it. So it blocked.
. I Give up!

bpo:
That's interesting, as it does not work for me with git 1.7.11.1.

RFC 1738 describes valid URLs and why this doesn't work (specifically in 3.1, the format following the scheme is described as `//<user>:<password>@<host>:<port>/<url-path>`

Removing the description of URLs altogether is certainly an option - but if you want to be complete you just need to modify the syntax here slightly.

denisvmedia:
Просто слово "запутается" мне кажется имеющим несколько сниженную стилистическую окраску, выбивающуюся из общего текста. К тому же если посмотреть в оригинале - "things will get messy", а потом посмотреть определение слова messy:
1. Disorderly and dirty: a messy bedroom.
2. Exhibiting or demonstrating carelessness: messy reasoning.
3. Unpleasantly difficult to settle or resolve: a messy court case.
то увидим, что значения "запутанный" у слова нет.

Я в общем-то не настаиваю на своей формулировке, но когда читал в русском варианте, "все запутается" мне показалось весьма странной формулировкой, которая по моему мнению плохо отражает суть. Все-таки, наличие коммитов-близнецов это именно непорядок в истории (мусор, если грубо выразиться), а не путаница. Или даже так: беспорядок - причина, а путаница - следствие.

Но, повторюсь, я не настаиваю. До меня была проделана огромная работа, и не мне со своей однострочной правкой тут порядки наводить :)
. Как вариант, можно заменить мое слово "беспорядок" на "путаница". Смысл будет ближе к оригинальному переводу, а стилистика будет лучше.

That's almost the same. The verb tense is "imperative" which means "order" to do something, and that can be said "modifica" in 2nd person, and "modifichi" in 3rd person whether the speaker is on "first name terms" (to use the "lei" form with a person) or not.
. Exactly, If you use "esegui" than you use "modifica" because both are 2nd person, not 3rd, that would have been "esegua" :)

. Oh, be fair! There is not much more difficult than to create a system that works correctly always under every circumstances with the horrible abstract human concept of time.... Since Git doesn't record the time zone nor the calendarsystem of the entry (and "local" wouldn't cut it, as it would mean converting the entries every time the information is pulled and pushed) there is absolutely no way of getting the information out correctly, other than to assume every entry is in UTC, Zulu or at least something that is insensitive to both the changes in summer-/wintertimeshifts and the complexities of alternative calendar systems as Japanese, Korean, Islam and what have you.
If you are referring to "instant" do you refer to "instant" on your local machine or the "instant" on the machine which was used to commit the change to or the "instant" on the machine on which the pull-request was processed, or....
You get the picture: dates are relative and highly influenced by local parameters such as timezone, whether or not the daylight saving time is in effect or not (especially if it was in effect at time of committing at the source machine and not at yours) and whether the committer had set his time correctly.

I'm not saying that this isn't a possibly important issue, but to just bagetalize the whole issue of time and dates..... that can be construed as condescending, don't you think? 

If you know how it can be solved: go ahead and resolve it, Git is an open source tool so you can send a pull-request with the solution and the world will be a better place.

rinopo:
Thanks!

According to the discussion progit-ja/progit#7 referenced above (of which I wasn't aware when I posted my PR), there indeed _is_ some risk about sending public keys over email: with plain email you can't really tell who really sent you the public key you receive.

Let's say Eve somehow knew that Bob is expecting to receive a public key from Alice via email. Eve may send her own public key to Bob pretending to be Alice, and Bob, not being able to uncover it, might allow Eve to let in instead of Alice.

You should either sign your email with PGP or have your key authorized by a CA to prevent this.

Although a thorough explanation of this might exceed the scope of our doc, it would be worthwhile noting it in some way or other, after all.
. Thanks!

nobozo:
I learned the hard way that making any substantial changes to this book via GitHub is hopeless. It appears that only translation additions/corrections and minor typo corrections are accepted. (Take a look at https://github.com/progit/progit/pull/485 for what I mean). It's almost not worth having the book sources available on GitHub because of this.

My solution to this problem was to fork my own version of Pro Git and create a new version that I call Pro Git Reedited to contain all my changes.(https://github.com/nobozo/progitreedited). This isn't the way I hoped things would go.

Scott Chacon is very busy working at GitHub so I can understand why he delegated control of the Pro Git sources. I wonder, however, if he's aware of people like you and me who try to make improvements to the book. I also wonder what he's going to do about Pro Git 2nd Edition, if and when it ever comes out. There's a You Tube video (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OfBwFkNaoUo) where he talks about that but from what I can tell he ignores any attempts to communicate about it. This is too bad since he did a great service by writing Pro Git in the first place. It would be nice if it were possible to contribute  to a second edition.

Jon Forrest

# SAME date-and-time used for  --after          AND          --before
```

...returns a **non**-empty result, namely the following commit: [c9599c6c03bdad4413475f56a9b5ddb0f56b3342](https://github.com/progit/progit/commit/c9599c6c03bdad4413475f56a9b5ddb0f56b3342)
. Be sure to do `git pull origin master` first, since I'm referencing a very recent commit; and if you have not pulled it down yet, the result will be empty.

```

  Note that commit c9599c6c03bdad4413475f56a9b5ddb0f56b3342 
  was made on 2014-04-27 at **18:54:12**
  - So wait until your local time is shortly **before 18:54:12** (e.g. 18:50:00) and run
  
        `LC_ALL=C  git log --after="2014-04-27"` --> should include commit c9599c6c03bdad4413475f56a9b5ddb0f56b3342
  - Then wait until your local time is shortly **after 18:54:12** (e.g. 18:55:00) and run
  
         `LC_ALL=C  git log --after="2014-04-27"` --> should **not** include commit c9599c6c03bdad4413475f56a9b5ddb0f56b3342

. Interesting. 

Seems like this means that command `git log --after="2014-04-27"` when run at 09:00:00 at summer-time is equiv with
`git log --after="2014-04-27 09:00:00"`

but when run at 09:00:00 in winter-time (e.g. when you are in France) is equivalent with
`git log --after="2014-04-27 10:00:00"`

???

I really had think about  umm +1 or -1, but I think for France it should be correct. ;)
. `git log`'s date treatment (example: `git log --after=<date>`) just seems to be plain broken (and frustrating to work with).

To see it, try this:

```
git clone https://github.com/octocat/Spoon-Knife.git spoon_knife
cd spoon_knife
git log --after="2014-02-04 14:38:25 -0800" --date=iso
```

This **incorrectly** return a commit that was made 1 second before: `2014-02-04 14:38:24 -0800` (iso format)

**What's the proper command to get all commits on-or-after the instant in time at exactly `2014-02-04 14:38:25 -0800` ??????**

_Git "the stupid content tracker" -- so stupid that it cannot even get date-handling right???_
. Aha!!

`git log --after=<date>` considers all commits with **CommitDate on-or-after** `<date>`

To see this try:

```
git clone https://github.com/octocat/Spoon-Knife.git spoon_knife
cd spoon_knife
TZ="UTC" git log --date=local --after="2014-02-12 23:18:55" --pretty=fuller # show all commits with CommitDate on-or-after 2014-02-12 23:18:55 (here relative to UTC)
TZ="UTC" git log --date=local --after="2014-02-12 23:18:56" --pretty=fuller # show all commits with CommitDate on-or-after 2014-02-12 23:18:56 (here relative to UTC)
```

In order for `<date>` to work well (and repeatably, irrespective of your timezone), it is best to use an absolute time (that includes timezone information).
A good absolute time to choose is ISO time.

Examples:
- convert a time from Paris time to (absolute) ISO time

       `TZ="Europe/Paris"       date --date="2014-02-12 12:00:30" -Is` 
       or
       `TZ="posix/Europe/Paris" date --date="2014-02-12 12:00:30" -Is`

       This returns `2014-02-12T12:00:30+0100`, which shows that Paris is 1 hour ahead of UTC. 
       Thus the equivalent UTC Time at that instant in time, would be 
       `TZ="UTC"              date --date='TZ="Europe/Paris" 2014-02-12 12:00:30' -Is`
       which returns `2014-02-12T11:00:30+0000`, confirming the fact.

So here's a recommendation for the progit book:
[...] if you want to see which commits modifying test files in the Git source code history were authored by Junio Hamano and **committed with CommitDate being in the month of October 2008 (relative to the timezone of New York)** and were not merges, you can run something like this:

```
git log --pretty="%h - %s" --author=gitster --after="2008-10-01T00:00:00-0400" --before="2008-10-31T23:59:59-0400" --no-merges -- t/
```

These date-and-times are absolute, since they include timezone information. (`-0400` means that New York is ahead of UTC by `-4 hours`, meaning that if it is midnight at UTC, then it is 20:00:00 in New York. If you are using bash then these absolute times can be determined like this:
`TZ="America/New_York" date --date="2008-10-01 00:00:00" -Is`. The prefix `TZ="..."` can be determined using `tzselect`).
(But the progit book should perhaps use a better example, that lists the CommitDate...)

PS:
How Do you determine your timezone under GNU/Linux?

```
LC_ALL=C timedatectl status | sed -rn 's/^[[:space:]]*Timezone:[[:space:]]*([^[:space:]]+).*$/\1/p'
```

In order to work well with times, we need good ways of converting between them. The `date` program is perfect for this. Here are some useful examples:

```
TZ="Europe/Paris"     date --date="2014-02-12 23:18:56" -Is     # convert a time from Paris time to (absolute) ISO time

TZ="America/New_York" date --date='TZ="Europe/Paris" 2014-02-12 23:18:56'           # convert a time from      Paris time to New_York time
TZ="UTC"              date --date='TZ="Europe/Paris" 2014-02-12 23:18:56'           # convert a time from      Paris time to UTC
date -u                    --date='TZ="Europe/Paris" 2014-02-12 23:18:56'           # convert a time from      Paris time to UTC (alternative)

TZ="America/New_York" date --date=$(date     --date="2014-02-12 23:18:56" -Is)      # convert a time from your current TZ to New_York time
TZ="UTC"              date --date=$(date     --date="2014-02-12 23:18:56" -Is)      # convert a time from your current TZ to UTC
date -u                    --date=$(date     --date="2014-02-12 23:18:56" -Is)      # convert a time from your current TZ to UTC  (alternative)
TZ="America/New_York" date                                                          # convert "now"  from your current TZ to New_York time
```
. > Well does someone still get empty results when doing
> 
> ```
>   LC_ALL=C git log --after="2014-04-27 18:54:12" --before="2014-04-27 18:54:12"
> ```
> 
> on the progit repo's main branch????

In order to get non-empty results (irrespective of your timezone and location), please use this instead:

```
git log --date=iso --after="2014-04-27T18:54:12+0200"  --before="2014-04-27T18:54:12+0200"  --pretty=fuller
git log --date=iso --after="2014-04-27 18:54:12 +0200" --before="2014-04-27 18:54:12 +0200" --pretty=fuller   # alternative
```

This proves that `--after` means _on-or-after a specific CommitDate_ and `--before` mean _on-or-before a specific CommitDate_. ;)
. Just note that `--date=iso` or `--date=local` just changes the way the date is displayed in the log. The fields `--after` and `--before` are not affected by this, and use your current timezone, unless you provide an absolute time (which you should, so that your colleagues around the world get the same repeatable results!), as can be obtained using e.g.

```
TZ="Europe/Paris" date --date="2008-10-01 00:00:00" -Is     # get absolute time
                                                            # use tzselect to find strings for TZ="..."
```
. I hope the above commit will help fellow coders better understand date-time handling in `git log`; and reduce frustration.
Included are important best practices, such as how to formulate `git log` commands (that include dates and times) in such a manner, that they will gives the same results for all your colleagues , irrespective of where in the world (differing timezones!) they are located; etc. ;)
